text: When my mother's Alzheimer's got bad,
I was going through her bills,
Written on it were the words
Not to give her heart away?
Not to leave the sprinklers on?
We didn't exactly talk a lot in those days.
I regret that. I wish we had.
I thought you said you and Dr. Cohen
- had clean margins in the mastectomy. - Yeah, we did.
But then, a spot showed up on the latest scans
- So you didn't. - It could be nothing.
Or it could be leftover cells
that weren't taken out and kept growing.
We don't know what it is, really,
Yeah, I'll do a wide local excision,
explore the area, remove anything I find.
We may need to do a muscle flap just to cover the defect,
No, it has to be tomorrow,
The next day at the latest.
We should let her get stronger first.
And we don't want it to spread past what it already has.
Of course we don't, but it's a big surgery, so...
I want the next surgery as soon as you can do it.
which made things a little tricky.
I would've preferred to have waited another week.
I'm sorry. I haven't followed up on the... the thing.
It's not because I don't want to.
Sure, I mean, you know, if...
There is a lot going on.
This chair's the only place my stomach and back
I have three kids. I don't sleep.
so Maggie could have a sister or a brother.
I was worried when she wanted to move out here.
but... I'm really glad she found you.
You said your stomach is bothering you?
It's right where the bile drains from your liver,
so that would explain your pain.
You're saying I have another tumor?
No. No, she's saying that cells from the original tumor
have traveled and grown in another place.
So, I know this is a lot to take in.
So why don't the two of you, um, take the night,
and we can meet again in the morning
- What? - Well, that would be better
than an open procedure at this point, right?
Then we wouldn't have to stop her chemo regimen,
unless you have a different surgical plan.
Would you like to discuss this outside?
No, no. We're discussing my mother's treatment.
- We can discuss it with her. - Okay.
we only operate where the original tumor began...
in this case, it was your breast.
Unless the cancer spreads beyond that, surgery is not curative.
But it could prevent further pain and complications,
which there will be if the met keeps growing
And we would work to prevent that using other options.
Sure, pump her with more chemo.
Well, a second ago, you were worried
You're asking me to perform a procedure...
You can barely see it on the scan.
...that will not only cause her pain,
- It's my mother! - for many complications.
I'm asking you to think beyond the standard and typical.
And I'm asking you to listen to yourself as a surgeon,
- who should know better... - Oh, good God, enough!
Both of you... I can't even hear myself think.
Mama, we just... we need one...
that you can't do the surgery
- to remove the, um... - The met.
I can, but I'm saying that I won't
I think it's a terrible idea.
Meredith, if you won't do the surgery, you should go.
We'll find another surgeon who will.
Maggie, this is not your decision to make.
You're no longer one of my doctors.
Thank you for meeting with me this morning.
I found something that... it is called the BXP protocol,
They are experimenting with humanized antibodies
The trial's next phase was rushed into approval
And your mom meets the criteria?
Once we remove that met that's obstructing her bile duct,
her liver enzymes will go down, and she's in.
Um, Meredith doesn't feel that surgery is wise.
Meredith is no longer on the case.
And now that I know about this trial,
there is even more reason to do the surgery.
And I'd like one of you to do it.
I think we should read up on the trial...
...and then come up with a plan.
Does that sound good to you?
Does anyone think this is a good idea?
All right, so we're together on that.
So, I'll bring up, uh, Diane's chart.
We'll pull together some other research and get together,
see what we can come up with, huh?
You know what? I'd prefer to work alone.
No, no, no, no, guys, that's not a good idea.
given the location and size of the met.
Are you actually going to resect it?
The met? I'm not going near that thing.
Right now, I'm just trying to figure out
how to lower her LFTs to get her into this trial.
Mm, that's still surgery. I mean, with her condition...
But if it's done percutaneously, under minimal sedation...
Yeah, it could give her long-term relief,
Well, it's better than a complete bypass.
How are her LFTs post-op? Any change?
- And her LFTs are trending down, yes. - Mm-hmm.
So she'll qualify for the trial.
Yes, she qualifies for the trial.
Oh, my God. That is amazing news!
Ah! Thank you, Dr. Bailey, for doing the procedure!
Oh! I gotta call my contacts at Gillman.
I... I got to go. All right, thank you.
No one wanted to mention that we think that the trial
You need to sit her down and let her know what's going on.
- Me? I'm not doing that! - You're her friend.
Who kept her mom's cancer a secret from her.
No, you're her dad. You do it.
- So was Avery. - Oh, come on.
You led the procedure that brought her LFTs down
and got her the trial in the first place.
A trial I never believed in.
Well, who's head of the board?
- Now you care about that? - Never mind.
Oh. Maggie went to get me some tea or something.
You know, I wanted to chat...
Well, yes, y-y-you will, but, listen.
- There are some things that... - Maggie will be so excited.
She... She wants to start right away...
Will you be doing the protocol?
I want to make sure you have the complete picture.
the toll it's gonna take on your body...
But Maggie says it's a good idea.
Diane, there's a reason we don't let doctors
treat members of their own family.
Sometimes, the need to help someone you love
She wouldn't do anything to make me worse.
I'm gonna let you get some rest,
- Yeah. - Here you go, Ms. Pierce.
Oh, wha... no need for special treatment.
I... I'm happy in the other chemo room,
Right, Mom, it's a clinical trial
so, um, they have to be able
to control everything in your environment...
the room temperature, your temperature... everything.
I was going to ask Aurora
if Lee finally passed his driver's test.
Her son Lee has failed it twice,
and he was supposed to go to the DMV today.
Maggie, you work with these people.
How do you not know this?
Um, we will need you to sign these forms.
Yeah, well, the thing with clinical trials
is they can list a million ways your body might react,
but the truth is they just don't know.
You need to be prepared for anything.
Let me... Let me walk you through this.
Um, so... so, what this says
is you may experience some nausea and vomiting.
In short, it will get bad...
And then, if it starts to work,
hopefully you'll start to get a little better.
This treatment is killing her faster than the cancer.
Oh, I woke up hours ago feeling great.
So, I watched the news, did a little laundry.
Then I noticed that the pantry was a little cluttered,
Mom, you don't have to do that!
And you got up at the perfect time.
You're going to make my lasagna.
I-I don't... I... That's your thing.
I don't know how to make it.
I don't want you passing things down.
It's just that I have decided I don't have to do this anymore.
I am a woman of a certain age,
and I have earned the right to sit down, put my feet up,
and let you cook for me.
And you're not gonna like it when I'm gone
Okay, I just need to go, um, take a shower.
Hi! Why are you all here at once?
And we have wine. You guys,
she made me make the noodles from scratch.
You know you can buy noodles in a box, right?
And when I say she was reading, it was reading.
Maggie was not sounding out words or anything.
I have you to thank for that, I guess.
Well I don't know about that.
I'd like to pay my respects to Ellis.
I'm here, I'm staying in her house,
and it's the right thing to do.
That's very nice, but you don't need to do that.
- A place where she loved... - We dumped her ashes
down a scrub sink in OR 2.
Well, it was her favorite OR,
and it seemed like the right thing at the time.
- I just heard... an esophageal tear? - Yeah.
and I don't have to open her chest.
I should do the EGD. You're too close.
Let me do this for you.
Don't pretend you're doing this for me.
You've made it very clear for some time
that my well-being is the lowest of your priorities.
Do... Hey, I'm just trying to help.
you'd be the last person I'd call.
You had to do a thoracotomy?
Yeah. The tear was full thickness.
Conservative management wasn't the way to go here, Maggie.
So, we'll start her on tube feeds?
Um, we're... we're... we're not there yet.
Uh. She's on TPN for now,
and I'm also concerned about sepsis,
so we've started her on broad-spectrum antibiotics.
She's still sedated for the pain,
and we'll keep her on PCA.
Do you need anything from home?
Do you want us to get you anything?
We need to get her on her feet ASAP.
If she misses any of her infusions,
she'll lose her position in the study.
- Maggie... - I'd like for us to get Diane
And then, we'll... we'll see where we are from there.
trying to talk me out of anything right now.
This protocol is making Diane so sick
That could just be from the cancer.
But you can't wait to get her to her next infusion.
Because my mom wants to live!
And this clinical trial could give that to her.
How can she say "no" when her daughter,
who is a surgeon, is standing right there,
I just need to get her to the end of the treatment.
She won't make it to the end of the treatment.
She's already dying, and now she's suffering because of it.
At least I'm not just giving up and saying "no."
We are only doing her harm.
You don't get it! You wouldn't!
Meredith, I love my mother enough
and throw her down a damn drain.
you don't have to keep putting yourself through this.
Not if you don't want to.
I was born in a two-room shack with an outhouse,
not a lot of food or love or... anything.
When that social worker put this little baby in my arms,
when I looked down at my Maggie...
Maggie is the universe giving me a gift.
to the most special person in the whole world?
When I die, she needs to know
that she did everything that she could.
Maggie's done everything there is to do.
I can't stop. I-I can't do that to her.
You may not see it, because you knew her
since she was a little girl.
I only know the woman you raised.
And that woman is smart and strong as iron,
especially for the people she loves.
now I see where she gets it.
So, I'm gonna put out a couple of calls
to some old professors from Boston.
Don't you dare quit on me now.
Y-You can't. You can't quit on me.
You have to fight. I'll help you.
Sit down and let me talk to you.
Get those to the lab for me. Thank you.
Do you want to sit down?
I just wish my dad was here.
My mom has been sick for months without me knowing...
I feel like I left the house with the oven on
the whole house engulfed in flames.
And no one will let me in.
- No matter what I do, I can't get inside.
I could've stopped it if I had known.
S-So, I can't give up. I can't give up, not now.
Talk about whatever she wants to talk about
and record her voice in your mind
You don't have to go there right now.
They're not a gift. It's your right.
Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.
Sometimes, I like to wait until right before bedtime, but...
Oh, did you call about my eyelashes?
You know I wanna die with my eyelashes on.
and you never messed around with the boys.
You need to shake it up a little.
Well, you're never gonna look back and say,
Okay, Mom, you have to be still,
or else I can't finish this.
And stop always saying what everyone wants to hear.
It's good for 'em and better for you.
Especially if it's a car salesperson.
- Do you like the color? - I do.
- And don't forget the t... - The topcoat, I know.
I brought my engagement ring to Seattle.
It's at the house in my jewelry bag,
and I want you to have it.
- Mom. - Your father gave it to me.
He'd want you to have it, too.
I want you to fall in love.
And it has to be somebody who's worthy.
Find a decent man who loves you
just a little more than you love him.
How about equally as much? How about that?
No, he needs to think he is lucky to have you
and not the other way around.
Never make yourself small for anyone.
And try wearing a little lipstick.
You know, Mom, if you keep going at this rate,
you're gonna run out of advice before tomorrow.
Want me to open a window?
Okay, I'm not gonna leave it open too long,
Bring you to a hospital, help you catch a cold.
Listen, I... I-I know the flight...
and so I'll write you a check.
Yeah. I'm sorry to hear about Diane.
For how long, I don't know.
Our timing's just... off, I guess.
I think about my mom's note all the time.
Not to cave? Not to care?
Not to give up so easily?
...what to do, what not to do.
She left me knowing everything was up to me.
She went to her grave without forgiving me.
It robbed me of so many things...
Let's not do that to each other.
And she left me with no one to ask.
So I would decide what she meant to write.
